title: Cooling effect of Montréal parks minimally affected by historical legacies
section: How do complicated histories interact with park benefits?
text:
How do complicated histories interact with park benefits?


Do the communities surrounding parks differ socio-demographically by past land-use type? If so, do these differences continue legacies of environmental racism?
What are the legacy effects of past land-use types on current park capacity to provide a temperature mitigation, a critical benefit?

title: Cooling effect of Montréal parks minimally affected by historical legacies

section: Collecting Montréal park trees and temperatures
text: Collecting Montréal park trees and temperatures

title: Cooling effect of Montréal parks minimally affected by historical legacies
text:
The “Luxury Effect” around our parks
In the neighbourhoods surrounding our parks we see:

Lower proportions of visible minorities
Higher proportions of highly educated people
Higher incomes (except in previously industrial parks)
More single detached homes (except in previously industrial parks)

section: Let’s put parks everywhere! (with thought and community-led policy)
text:
Let’s put parks everywhere! (with thought and community-led policy)



Park cooling happens everywhere
Legacy effects still dominate close to parks
Parks in industrial areas have the potential to increase equity, if done correctly
